STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 16, 2022
Mark Jordan
Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
RE: License #: CP350201199
Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
Dear Mr. Jordan:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/15/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (866) 685-0006.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP350201199
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Leo Giori Jr, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
Facility Address: 2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
Facility Telephone #: (989) 362-0300
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1992
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the
reevaluation. The placement specifications shall include all
of the following:
(a) Age,
One of the three current foster home files included a foster home reevaluation report
that did not include the age range of children appropriate for placement in the home.
The report was a renewal report dated 07/21/2022. The corresponding license
(3706) indicated an age range of 0-16 years.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited 10/8/2021 INTERIM, CAP
Approved 11/03/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the foster parent's
role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed contained an updated service
plan time period that did not include the development of a Parent Agency Treatment
Plan (PATP) for the foster parent providing care for the child placed as required by
this rule. In this example the time period was 06/03/2022 to 06/28/2022. There
were PATPs for the parents but one for the caregiver could not be located.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
4

The one independent living record reviewed did not contain adequate documentation
of the rationale for the selection of independent living as the most appropriate
placement for the youth. Assessments to determine appropriateness were not
located and updated service plans were inadequate in demonstrating
appropriateness. The identified independent living placement date was 03/14/2022.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's housing,
clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is available.
The one independent living record reviewed did not include the documentation of a
budget to provide proof there was adequate support to meet the youth’s housing,
clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses as needed. The identified independent
living placement date was 03/14/2022.
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth's record.
The one independent living record reviewed included a medical passport with the
most recent signature date of 06/26/2022, but it did not include documentation the
youth had received an updated physical as required. The most recent physical was
dated 08/01/2019 and there was no documentation the youth had signed a waiver
for medical services to meet this requirement.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(n) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
5

The one independent living record reviewed did not include the documentation
required for the all of the changes in placement that were documented for the youth.
In this example the record for the youth indicated changes in placement 07/28/2021,
12/03/2021, 03/10/2022, and 03/14/2022. A DHHS 69 was completed/provided to
document the change 12/03/2021, but it was not dated as to when it was completed.
This required form of documentation was not located for the other identified changes
in placements.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited 10/8/2021 INTERIM, CAP
Approved 11/03/2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
The one independent living record reviewed did not include an independent living
contract containing the information required by this rule.
R 400.12511 Independent living contract.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living services
for a youth, the agency shall document all of the following
information in the case record within 30 calendar days of
termination of its services:
(a) The reason for the termination.
(b) The youth’s new location.
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and the
needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
The one discharged independent living record did not include the required
documentation as required by this rule. In this example the youth was identified as
discharged 02/02/2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which
will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
Six of the seven youth records reviewed had at least one Updated Service Plan or
PATP uploaded into the information system without the required/dated signatures
for the documents. The importance of this issue was discussed at the time of the
6

exit conference.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 801-3 The health screens within the MiSACWIS Health Profile section
must be updated quarterly to ensure the child's current health information is
up-to-date and accurate.
Four of the seven current foster child records reviewed did not include
documentation to indicate the medical passport information was updated/signed
at least quarterly as required. The first example did not have a signed medical
passport. The second example had a signed medical passport, but it was not
dated so compliance could not be determined. The third example had a passport
with the most recent signature date of 09/23/2021. The fourth example had a
passport with the most recent signature date of 03/02/2021.
FOM 722-06B The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
Six of the seven foster child records reviewed contained at least one FTM that did
not include documentation that the DHS-1105 had been completed as required to
document the FTM activity. A total of 23 FTM’s were documented as completed
and the DHS-1105 was located as being completed for seven of them.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 The agency was reminded to generate/save reports, to make them accessible
under the documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
 PATPs must have dates with the signatures to verify they were signed within
the required timeframe.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
None
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the interim evaluation completed
10/08/2021. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that evaluation were 324
(4)(a), 327(7), 405(4), 418(2)(b), and 509(3)(n). The corrective action plan was
submitted 10/26/2021 and approved 11/03/2021.
7

Trends and Repeat Violation Assessment
Areas identified as repeat noncompliance as a part of this renewal evaluation are
324(4)(a) and 509(3)(n).
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was a review of the progress in
monitoring/completing the corrective action plan for the interim evaluation completed
10/08/2021. Staffing issues affecting services and the status of Key Performance
Indicators were also included. Ongoing supervision/monitoring activities were also
presented.
Interviews
Child Welfare staff participated in entrance and exit conferences with no concerns
indicated.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
08/16/2022
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
08/16/2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
